name: ONS survey highlights pre-existing conditions most commonly associated with Covid-19 deaths
summary: Men, the elderly and people with pre-existing health conditions are most likely to die due to coronavirus, official data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has confirmed.

name: More than 150,000 self-employed not covered by government support scheme
summary: Some 151,000 started self-employment after March 2019, new data has revealed – meaning they are not eligible for help under the government’s Covid-19 support scheme.

name: 8,000 more deaths than normal in week to 10 April, ONS says
summary: Nearly 8,000 more people than normal died in the week ending 10 April, with the bulk of the extra deaths directly attributed to Covid-19, the latest data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has revealed.

name: Latest worldwide death stats suggest peak has passed, but not in the US
summary: The latest figures for Covid-19 deaths across the countries hit hardest by the virus suggest the peak of the pandemic has passed – but the data from the US paints a very different picture.

name: Covid-19 daily report: Death toll trends inch downwards in worst-hit nations
summary: All the countries worst hit by the coronavirus outbreak – the US, Spain, Italy, France and the UK – have seen their number of daily deaths fall in the past seven days.

name: Half of coronavirus business grants in England still unclaimed
summary: Businesses in Nottingham, Birmingham and Manchester have claimed less than a fifth of the coronavirus emergency support available to them, new government figures reveal.

name: Worldwide coronavirus death rate rises after US spike
summary: There were 7,793 deaths from Covid-19 reported around the world yesterday, the highest daily increase since last Friday, 17 April.

name: 27,000 more deaths than normal since start of coronavirus pandemic, ONS says
summary: England and Wales saw 27,000 more deaths than would normally be expected between the start of March, when the coronavirus pandemic took hold, and 17 April, new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show.

name: Up to one in 17 care home residents may have died since the Covid-19 outbreak started. Why?
summary: After 20,836 people died in the five weeks to 17 April, care homes have become the new epicentre of the disease.

name: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died since outbreak began
summary: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died in just five weeks since the start of the Covid-19 outbreak, Nicu Calcea reports. New data released on 28 April showed that the number of care home deaths has gone beyond “alarming” and is becoming a national scandal.

name: Death rate in most deprived areas double that of richest neighbourhoods
summary: People in the most deprived areas of England and Wales are dying at more than twice the rate of those in the most affluent places, new data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) shows.

name: Berlin has biggest rise in public transport use and traffic congestion among world cities
summary: Some world cities are seeing an increased movement of people even before lockdown restrictions are eased, our weekly city mobility chart shows.

name: Renters and the self-employed have taken biggest financial hit from pandemic
summary: More than half of self-employed workers say their household finances have suffered during the Covid-19 crisis, according to new data from the Office for National Statistics.

name: Major European cities registering biggest drops in daily Covid-19 cases
summary: The number of confirmed Covid-19 cases is falling in major cities across the world, with countries in Europe registering the biggest drops in daily new cases.

name: Crime in Northern Ireland falls by a third during lockdown
summary: Crime in Northern Ireland fell by nearly a third in the five weeks starting 23 March, according to new figures that give us a first glimpse of how the coronavirus lockdown has affected crime in the UK.

name: Covid-19 cases continue to fall in major worldwide cities
summary: The number of new daily Covid-19 cases continues to drop in major cities and regions in Europe and the US, while Wuhan has recorded its first new cases since the end of the lockdown.

name: US daily deaths now double UK, Spain and France combined
summary: The US recorded 1,156 Covid-19 deaths yesterday, which is more than the reported totals for the UK, Spain and France combined.

name: Economic forecasts worsen in Europe, Italy faces biggest slump
summary: GDP growth forecasts for major European countries and the US have been revised downwards yet again, with France seeing the biggest change from last week.

name: Number of patients waiting six or more weeks for diagnostic tests highest since 2008
summary: The number of people waiting six or more weeks for a diagnostic test in England nearly tripled in March 2020, as Covid-19 saw hospital postpone “non-urgent” treatment.

name: A&E attendance falls to record low
summary: Attendance at accident and emergency departments in England plunged by more than half in April to a new record low.

name: Covid-19 cases may be seven times higher than previously thought, ONS testing suggests
Covid-19 involved in more than quarter of all care home deaths in recent months
summary: Coronavirus has accounted for more than a quarter of deaths in care homes since the start of the pandemic, figures published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) today showed.

name: North-west close to overtaking London as epicentre of UK’s Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The north-west of England is set to overtake London as the epicentre of the UK’s outbreak, latest data shows.

name: UK cities are awakening as lockdown is eased
summary: Walking and driving in the UK surged on Saturday, 16 May – the first weekend day since the government eased lockdown restrictions, new data show.

name: UK unemployment claims jump 69 per cent in April, a record rise
summary: The number of people claiming UK unemployment benefits increased to 2.1 million in April 2020, a monthly rise of 856,500 and the highest level since 1996.

name: “Excess deaths“ during pandemic top 50,000 in UK
summary: Around 50,000 more people have died in England and Wales since the start of the coronavirus outbreak than would normally be expected for this time of year, new figures show.

name: Has there been a “Cummings effect“ on lockdown compliance?
summary: The data shows increased mobility during the Cummings story, but it is harder to prove a causal link.

name: Why is the unemployment rate so much higher in the US than the EU?
summary: Differences in working culture and government responses have created a sharp divide. Which way will the UK go?

name: Record numbers of people in Britain can’t afford food – lifting lockdown won’t change that
summary: Even before Covid-19 hit, the proportion of households in the UK without the resources to eat was rising.

name: Britons are still staying at home because they don’t trust the government over Covid-19
summary: Data shows that UK residents are proving far more cautious about leaving lockdown than their European counterparts.

name: A lifetime of inequality: how black Britons face discrimination at every age
summary: From childbirth to retirement, statistics show the lifelong impact of systemic bias in modern Britain.

name: Is the Eat Out to Help Out scheme encouraging unhealthy eating?
summary: A New Statesman analysis estimates at least 10,667 of the restaurants currently registered are fast food outlets.

name: Why the coronavirus mental health crisis may not have peaked
summary: Nearly one in five people in the UK experienced some form of depression in June, up by 10 per cent the previous year.

name: Schools are set to reopen but how safe are they from Covid-19?
summary: Without a significantly improved test and trace programme, reopening schools could lead to a second wave in December.

name: Data analysis: How the poorest countries are losing out on Covid-19 relief funds
summary: New Statesman analysis suggests some countries with a higher GDP per capita have been allocated more international funding to fight the virus than poorer nations.

name: A third of UK residents are under local lockdowns – but has this changed their behaviour?
summary: People in most areas under strict Covid restrictions are only marginally less likely to go to pubs, restaurants and supermarkets.

name: Are pubs and restaurants to blame for the second wave of Covid-19?
summary: The hospitality industry has been singled out by Chris Whitty for spreading the virus, but the evidence is anything but clear-cut.

name: Hate crime is at a record high — but is there more hate, or more people reporting hate?
summary: Police in England and Wales recorded the highest ever number of hate crime incidents in the year up to March.

name: How the UK suffered 50,000 Covid-19 deaths – the highest number in Europe
summary: Only the US, Brazil, India and Mexico have recorded higher coronavirus death tolls than Britain.

name: What will a cashless China mean for the world?
summary: A new Chinese digital currency could help the country forge an alternative to the US-led global financial system.

name: Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah and the Great Smog of modern London
summary: Nearly 70 years on from the Great Smog of London, air pollution still haunts Britain’s environmental efforts – and its most deprived places.

name: Mapping the unequal impact of Brexit
summary: The New Statesman’s data team has created a Brexit vulnerability index, using data from every local authority to show where the UK economy will be most affected.

name: How democracy could become one of the pandemic’s lasting victims
summary: New research suggests the world has become increasingly autocratic since the start of the Covid-19 crisis.

name: Covid-19: a tragedy in numbers
summary: Only Belgium, Slovenia and San Marino have recorded higher coronavirus death rates than the UK.

name: Which councils are hitting their apprenticeship targets?
summary: Our analysis shows some local authorities are better than others.

name: Pandemic winners and losers: how Big Tech’s gains mask a struggling economy
summary: A global lockdown has caused dramatic shifts in the economic landscape and focused markets on one sector.

name: Britain’s hidden health crisis: How overcrowded housing may be spreading Covid-19
summary: New Statesman analysis reveals cramped housing conditions could be increasing coronavirus transmission, disproportionately endangering society’s most vulnerable.

name: How much has Brexit cost the UK?
summary: Two months after the UK’s full departure from the EU, the painful consequences of that decision are becoming ever clearer.

name: UK economic recovery tracker: the effects of Brexit and Covid-19 on jobs, house prices, trade and spending
summary: We’ve tracked a range of economic indicators to see how Britain is weathering the events of the past year.

name: Why is Israel doing so much better than Chile at coming out of lockdown?
summary: Both countries have high vaccination rates, but the difference in Covid case rates can serve as a lesson to the UK.

name: Britain is becoming the sick man of the G20
summary: Our trackers show the UK’s economic recovery will be slower than that of almost any other advanced economy.

name: Why India desperately needs more Covid-19 vaccines
summary: India is struggling with a lethal second wave and only 9 per cent of its population has received at least one vaccine.

name: Prolific yet quiet: Joe Biden’s first 100 days in numbers
summary: The US president has set about reversing Donald Trump’s legacy, but a smaller media profile and split Senate point to challenges ahead.

name: “It’s our Brexit”: Will low traffic neighbourhoods affect the local election results?
summary: As Covid-19 restrictions ease and amid talk of a vaccine bounce, road closures across the country could also be driving voters.

name: Labour struggles as the Tories and Greens surge – the final local election results
summary: Keir Starmer’s party lost 326 council seats, while Boris Johnson’s gained 235.

name: Pubs and cafés are back – but the UK economy will be slow to recover
summary: Britain’s economic recovery has been muted so far, and a cautious return to retail and hospitality could be slowed by the prospect of another wave of infections.

name: How the UK became a stage for hate during the Israel-Palestine conflict
summary: Reports of hate incidents against both Jews and Muslims in the UK have increased over the past two weeks.

name: How the Indian Covid variant has surged in England
summary: The variant now accounts for up to 75 per cent of new coronavirus cases.

name: How Joe Biden’s popularity in the UK far exceeds Donald Trump’s
summary: The new US president is currently the second most popular foreign politician among the British public.

name: How the G7’s economic power has diminished
summary: As the group's dominance of the global economy shrinks, is it time to reinvent its membership?

name: UK house prices grow at fastest rate in 16 years
summary: House prices in Britain rose by an annual rate of 13.4 per cent in June 2021, the highest since 2004.

name: Bubble trouble: pupil Covid-19 school absences quadrupled in June
summary: Some schools in England have closed entirely this month as rising numbers of children are sent home and fewer take regular tests.

name: UK Covid-19 rates are the highest of any European country after Cyprus
summary: Coronavirus cases in Britain have reached their highest level since January with 221,000 in the last week.

name: How the EU has overtaken the US on Covid-19 vaccines
summary: More than 57 per cent of EU residents have now received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine.

name: Smoking-related cancers are twice as high among England’s poorest
summary: A new report estimates there are some 11,247 smoking-related cancer cases each year among those in England’s most deprived areas, compared to just 6,200 in the least deprived areas.

name: How the US and the UK accept far fewer Afghan refugees than other countries
summary: The UK took in 9,351 Afghan refugees in 2020, while Germany accommodated 148,000.

name: China’s income inequality is among the world’s worst
summary: The gap between the rich and poor in China is almost as huge as in the US.

name: How the NHS now dominates public spending
summary: Health and social care will soon account for 40 per cent of the UK government’s day-to-day spending, up from 30 per cent a decade ago.

name: Five fossil fuel companies are suing governments for more than $18bn
summary: Firms are taking legal action after their profits were affected by climate policies.

name: Why China’s pledge to end coal funding abroad is a dramatic moment
summary: Xi Jinping’s country had planned to build more than 56,135 megawatts worth of coal infrastructure by 2050.

name: The Universal Credit reduction is the biggest overnight benefit cut in history
summary: The £1,040-a-year benefit cut is the biggest since the creation of the British welfare state.

name: How Covid-19 vaccines have dramatically reduced deaths
summary: The ratio of deaths to total cases has changed from 3 per cent during the second wave to just 0.3 per cent last week.

name: Why the world must abandon coal power to avoid climate catastrophe
summary: Western countries need to completely phase out coal by 2030 to limit global warming to below 1.5°C.

name: Which countries are the biggest carbon emitters in history?
summary: China and India are far behind countries such as the US and UK for cumulative emissions.

name: Exclusive: Tory MPs would be over £1m worse off in six months with Boris Johnson’s second job ban
summary: Original New Statesman analysis finds Conservative MPs in political consultancy or similar advisory roles over the past six months earned £1,088,036 between them.

name: Where are the people attempting to cross the Channel coming from?
summary: At least 167 migrants have died or gone missing on the English Channel route since 2014, not counting those who drowned on 24 November.

name: How UK wages are stagnating
summary: Boris Johnson has promised a “high-wage economy”, but pay growth was flat in the year to October.

name: The Covid-19 pandemic made us fall in love with Christmas songs
summary: Our data team has tracked the performance of nearly 200 merry tunes released since the turn of the millennium.

name: How does the cost of the BBC TV licence compare to streaming?
summary: At £13.25 a month, the licence fee is cheaper than Netflix’s premium tier and Sky’s streaming service.

name: How Europe is hooked on Russian gas
summary: The EU’s reliance on imports of the fuel from its eastern neighbour has only grown since the 2014 annexation of Crimea.

name: How Portugal’s Socialists triumphed in the general election
summary: The prime minister António Costa has won an unexpected majority after six years in office.

name: Will Ukraine be the source of Europe’s next migrant crisis?
summary: Up to 1.5 million Ukrainians were internally displaced by Russia’s 2014 invasion of the country.

name: Was Sweden’s Covid-19 policy really successful?
summary: The country’s death rate is more than double that of Denmark, the next most affected Nordic state.

name: How the Russian rouble has plummeted to a record low
summary: Following the imposition of Western sanctions the rouble is now worth less than one US cent.

name: Russia cracks down on protesters across the country
summary: More than 12,000 people have been detained for protesting since Russia's invasion of Ukraine

name: War in Ukraine threatens to create a global food crisis
summary: Grains, fertiliser and fuel are soaring in price.

name: Personal inflation calculator: how do you compare to the rest of Britain?
summary: Our calculator shows how you could be affected by surging prices in the UK.

name: Record-high temperatures in Antarctica leave scientists worried
summary: Temperatures peaked at 40°C above their normal level for this time of year.

name: How the centre-left and centre-right in France collapsed
summary: The Socialists and Republicans, the two traditional governing parties, have suffered their worst election results in history.

name: How Right to Buy fuelled the housing crisis
summary: Many council homes sold through the scheme ended up on the private rental market.

name: How CEO pay has returned to pre-pandemic levels
summary: The median FTSE 100 chief executive was paid £3.6m in 2021.

name: How scammers are exploiting the war in Ukraine
summary: Spotlight analysis reveals a spike in registrations of domains referencing the conflict.

name: How the cryptocurrency market has crashed
summary: The main crypto index shows that prices are 72 per cent below their peak.

name: Software is becoming more interdependent, and that’s a big security problem
summary: Recent incidents have highlighted the risks of relying on a growing ecosystem of third-party software packages.

name: Hundreds of Ukrainian families are being left homeless in the UK
summary: At least 660 Ukrainian households have found themselves with nowhere to stay.

name: Shooting deaths in the US reveal the deadly cost of America’s gun obsession
summary: There were 39,682 deaths from guns in 2019, the worst rate in the developed world.

name: Which countries could Putin try to ‘protect’ next?
summary: The Kremlin has used the pretext of defending Russian speakers to threaten former Soviet states.

name: How the rise of buy-to-let landlords fuelled the housing crisis
summary: First-time buyers have been priced out of the housing market by wealthier people.

name: How UK cash withdrawals have reached a record high
summary: The cost-of-living crisis has led to a 20 per cent year-on-year rise in cash withdrawals.

name: Two thirds of UK families to enter fuel poverty by January
summary: If annual bills rise to £4,200, 66 per cent of families will be considered fuel-poor.

name: Can your favourite pub afford to keep the lights on this winter?
summary: Business electricity spending is set to rise rapidly in October.

name: How much territory does Ukraine control? Use this interactive map to find out
summary: The New Statesman's interactive map shows the size of Ukraine's occupied territory when compared to other countries
